channel.title: World News - Breaking international news and headlines | Sky News

image.title: World News - Breaking international news and headlines | Sky News

channel.description: The latest international news from Sky, featuring top stories from around the world and breaking news, as it happens.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021, Sky UK. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Evacuation of women and children rescued from Mariupol steelworks is delayed
item.description: Civilians rescued from a holdout district in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol have not arrived at a safe location as expected.
item.media:description: A child emerges from the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol during evacuations

item.title: UK sends £300m more in military aid to Ukraine as PM set to praise country's 'finest hour'
item.description: Boris Johnson will address the Ukrainian parliament on Tuesday, becoming the first world leader to do so since the outbreak of war in February.
item.media:description: In an essay in The New York Times, Mr Johnson said: 'The world is watching. It is not future historians but the people of Ukraine who will be our judge'

item.title: Top Ukrainian official says he doesn't think Russia will launch nuclear strike
item.description: The Ukrainian president's top aide says he does not believe Moscow will launch a nuclear strike against his country because Russia's decision-makers know they could end up dying in a global, nuclear war.
item.media:description: A view shows buildings destroyed by the shelling, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine, in Borodianka, Kyiv region, Ukraine, May 2, 2022. Picture taken with drone. REUTERS/Zohra Bensemra

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect claims he has an alibi that can be backed up
item.description: The man suspected of abducting Madeleine McCann insists he was many miles from the scene having sex in his camper van with a young woman who will back his alibi.
item.media:description: Christian B has been informed he is now an 'arguido' in Madeleine's disappearance - a formal suspect

item.title: Germany 'not against' ban on Russian oil - as EU considers the move in latest sanctions
item.description: Germany would be ready to back a European Union ban on Russian oil imports, two senior ministers have suggested.
item.media:description: 02 May 2022, Brandenburg, Schwedt: Surplus gas is burned on the industrial site of PCK-Raffinerie GmbH. Crude oil from Russia arrives at the PCK petroleum refinery in Schwedt via the "Friendship" pipeline. Last year, the Russian energy group Rosneft took over a large part of the PCK petroleum refinery in Schwedt. Rosneft is Russia's largest oil producer. According to its own information, the refinery in the Uckermark region processes 12 million tons of crude oil annually, making it one of the la

item.title: Amazon to reimburse employees $4,000 if they have to travel for an abortion
item.description: Internet retail giant Amazon will reimburse employees up to $4,000 (£3,202) in travel expenses if they have to travel for medical treatments, including an abortion.

item.title: 'I want to believe in a miracle': The desperate search for the thousands missing in Ukraine
item.description: The last time Tetiana Popovych spoke to her son was on the first of March.

item.title: Israel's fury at Sergei Lavrov's 'unforgiveable' claim that Hitler was part Jewish
item.description: Russia's foreign minister has been criticised for claiming Adolf Hitler "had Jewish origins" and "some of the worst antisemites are Jews".

item.title: 'Big moment in our reconnection with world': New Zealand welcomes back tourists as COVID rules eased
item.description: New Zealand has begun welcoming back tourists from more than 50 countries including Britain, the US, Canada and Japan for the first time in more than two years.
item.media:description: Families embrace after a flight from Los Angeles arrives at Auckland International Airport

item.title: 'We haven't even seen the worst of it': Bill Gates warns COVID pandemic may yet see 'more fatal' variants
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic is far from over, Bill Gates has warned, saying there could still be a variant which is "even more transmissive and even more fatal".
item.media:description: Bill Gates at COP26 in November
